_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Since 1914, Kemps LLC (Kemps) has been delighting families throughout the upper Midwest with wholesome and delicious dairy products. From our beginnings as a small creamery in Southeastern Minnesota, Kemps has extended its roots to include the manufacture and marketing of fresh milk, premium ice cream and frozen yogurt, frozen novelties, sour cream and cottage cheese through retail supermarkets and food service channels. Headquartered today in St. Paul, Minnesota, we operate five manufacturing facilities in Minnesota and Wisconsin and have over 1,126 employees.



Kemps is a wholly owned subsidiary of Dairy Farmers of America, Inc. 100% of our profits go to dairy farmers and their families.



The Kemps maintains a Safety Committee whose members are the designated incident commanders for the facility.  Kemps has an Emergency Response Plan (Plan) in effect to provide the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed at least once per year.  



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



?    Kemps is located at 200 20th Street North in Fargo, North Dakota.  The facility is situated between 1st and 3rd Avenues, approximately 0.3 miles north of State Highway 94 and 1.2 miles east of Interstate 29.  The immediate area is primarily industrial and commercial with residential areas to the north and northeast.  The primary ammonia equipment is located in an engine room.  The facility install ammonia sensors in the engine room that will provide remote warning of an ammonia leak.  



?    Ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the refrigeration process and is the only regulated substance on site.



?    The total ammonia inventory at the Kemps LLC / Cass Clay Creamery facility is 22,750 pounds.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PRE

VENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Kemps ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. For example, the facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and standards including the following:



?    IIAR Bulletin 107, "Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When Making Ammonia Refrigeration Tie-ins"

?    IIAR Bulletin 109, "Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe Ammonia Refrigeration System"

?    IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems"

?    IIAR, "A Guide to Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia Refrigeration System"



The facility, including the ammonia system was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. The ammonia refrigeration system is equipped with various automatic process controls which ensure safe and efficient operation of the compressors, condensers, evaporators and other process equipment, suction accumulator, and regulating valves.  In addition, pressure relief valves automatically engage in the event the system experiences a very high pressure situation.  In case of an ammonia leak, ammonia detectors will provide an alert.



From an administrative standpoint, the facility has implemented a Process Safety Management program for compliance with 29 CFR 1910.119 and a Risk Management Program for compliance with 40 CFR Part 68.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



An investigation into the Kemps accident history during the past Five-Year period, revealed that there have been no releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds (February 2009 - February 2014). In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release.



EMERG

ENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The following summarizes the emergency response and notification procedures at the facility:



1.    In the event of a spill, release, near miss, or threatened release involving ammonia, evacuate the immediate area and report the situation to the area supervisor.  If appropriate, hit the system emergency stop button.



2.    Area supervisor will contact the Operations Manager and the Maintenance Manager.  If both are not available (e.g. off-site), then the highest ranking supervisor on-site is contacted at the front office.  If needed, the Operations Manager and Maintenance Manager are contacted using pagers and/or telephone calls.



3.    When the evacuation alarm sounds, all employees should follow the evacuation procedures and evacuate the plant to ensure their safety. Currently, the facility evacuates its employees by the use of an alarm system and personal communication.  It is the responsibility of the management and supervisory staff to notify all employees of the need to evacuate.



4.    Call 911 to ensure public safety.  The Maintenance Manager or his designated alternate will evaluate the situation and determine appropriate response measures (e.g. use remote emergency switch to shut down equipment, clean up spills, etc.).



5.    Notify the appropriate agencies as required by law.



6.    Within 48 hours, a complete investigation must be performed.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



A Process Hazard Analysis study was conducted in 2012 to satisfy the requirements of the PSM and RMP regulations.  The team involved in the development of the analysis made several procedural/managerial recommendations to improve the safety at the facility.



DATA ELEMENT NOTES



Item numbers 7.10 (Compliance Audits), 7.11 (Incident Investigation), and 7.15 (Contractor Evaluation) have been intentionally left blank.  These items have been developed for Kemps and will be implemented when required.  In addition, the Emergency Action Plan outlines notification
procedures and reporting procedures in the event of an emergency, which could include fire, ammonia release, blackout, and power failure.
